review.title: Unbounded Human Learning: Optimal Scheduling for Spaced Repetition
review.abstract: In the study of human learning, there is broad evidence that our ability to retain a piece of information improves with repeated exposure, and that it decays with delay since the last exposure. This plays a crucial role in the design of educational software, leading to a trade-off between teaching new material and reviewing what has already been taught. A common way to balance this trade-off is via spaced repetition -- using periodic review of content to improve long-term retention. Though widely used in practice, there is little formal understanding of the design of these systems. This paper addresses this gap. First, we mine log data from a spaced repetition system to establish the functional dependence of retention on reinforcement and delay. Second, based on this memory model, we develop a mathematical framework for spaced repetition systems using a queueing-network approach. This model formalizes the popular Leitner Heuristic for spaced repetition, providing the first rigorous and computationally tractable means of optimizing the review schedule. Finally, we empirically confirm the validity of our formal model via a Mechanical Turk experiment. In particular, we verify a key qualitative insight and prediction of our model -- the existence of a sharp phase transition in learning outcomes upon increasing the rate of new item introductions.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The ability to learn and retain is an essential part of human life.

sections.heading: 1.1 Related Work
sections.text: The scientific literature on modeling human memory is highly active and dates back more than a century. One of the simplest memory models, the exponential oblivion curve, was first examined by Ebbinghaus in 1885 [9] - it models the likelihood of seeing an object as an exponentially decaying function of time that has elapsed since the previous review. The exact manner in which strength evolves as a function of ratings, the length of evaluation intervals, and other factors are a matter of debate, although there is a consensus about the existence of a distance effect leading to greater strength than mass evaluations (i.e., cracking).

sections.heading: 1.2 Our Contributions
sections.text: The main contributions of this paper fall into two categories: First, the paper presents a principal methodology for designing review planning systems with different learning goals; second, the models we have developed provide qualitative insights and general principles for periodic review. sections.heading: 3. A STOCHASTIC MODEL FOR SPACED REPETITION SYSTEMS
sections.text: Based on the memory model developed in the previous section (as summarized in Eqn. 2), we now present a stochastic model for a repetition system with intervals and outline how we can use it to design good repetition positions. We reiterate that all existing systems for assigning repetition frequencies to decks in the Leitner system, and indeed in all other repetition systems with intervals, are based on heuristics without formal optimum guarantees. One of our key contributions is to provide a principle-driven method for determining appropriate timelines for spatial repetition systems. We focus on a regime in which the learner wants to memorize a very large amount of items - in particular the number of items available is much greater than the potential time required for memorization. A canonical example of such a setting is learning words in a foreign language that are always available to a new system (from a technical standpoint of view, this overrides the technical assumption that a new system is available to a new system).

sections.heading: 3.4 Extension to item-specific difficulties
sections.text: The assumption that all articles have the same difficulty can be eased by dividing difficulties into a fixed number of containers b and creating b parallel copies of the network. We now have b parallel Leitner Queue Networks coupled with the budget constraint that applies to the sum of service tariffs within the networks for each θ. We can assume that the traffics are a priori known (e.g. from log data or expert comments). To understand the effect of different affici, we compare the optimal schedule for different affici (but with the same budget U) in Fig. 12. The result is interesting because, to our knowledge, there is little understanding of how the user should adjust the frequency of deck checking when the general difficulty of articles changes. Fig. 12 suggests that for generally simple articles, the user should spend roughly the same amount of time on each deck; however, if articles are of higher general difficulty, the user should spend more time on higher decks than on lower ones.

sections.heading: 4. EXPERIMENTAL VALIDATION
sections.text: To empirically test the reliability of the Leitner Queue Network as a model for spatial repetition, we are conducting an experiment with Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) in which participants memorize words from a foreign language. Our study is designed to experimentally verify the existence of the phase transition (Figure 5), the primary qualitative prediction of our model.

sections.heading: 4.1 Experiment Setup
sections.text: A total of 331 users ("turkers") on the MTurk platform were asked to participate in a vocabulary learning task. At the beginning of the task, the vocabulary used in the task was randomly selected from one of two categories: Japanese (words) and American Sign Language (animated gestures). Articles for the experiment were selected from the list of common words in both languages 4. In addition to calculating the observed throughput for the different arrival rates in the MTurk data, we calculate the average distribution of items across the five decks and the stack of masted items at the end of a session. This gives insight where items accumulate in unstable regimes. sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION AND OPEN QUESTIONS
sections.text: Our work develops the first formal mathematical model for thinking about repetition systems by far, which is validated by empirical data and provides a principle-based, computationally traceable algorithm for planning flashcards. Our formalization of the Leitner system suggests maximum learning speed as a natural design metric for repetition software by far; using techniques from queue theory, we derive a traceable program for calibrating the Leitner system to optimize learning speed. our queue system opens doors to the use of a large body of work in this area to develop more complex extensions. To inspire and facilitate future work in this direction, we publish (1) all the model and evaluation codes, (2) framework codes for conducting user studies, and (3) the data collected in our Mechanical Turk study to provide the data and code for replicating our experiments, which we provide online for further research at http: / hard.qi.us.

metadata.abstractText: In the study of human learning, there is broad evidence that our ability to retain information improves with repeated exposure and decays with delay since last exposure. This plays a crucial role in the design of educational software, leading to a trade-off between teaching new material and reviewing what has already been taught. A common way to balance this trade-off is spaced repetition, which uses periodic review of content to improve long-term retention. Though spaced repetition is widely used in practice, e.g., in electronic flashcard software, there is little formal understanding of the design of these systems. Our paper addresses this gap in three ways. First, we mine log data from spaced repetition software to establish the functional dependence of retention on reinforcement and delay. Second, we use this memory model to develop a stochastic model for spaced repetition systems. We propose a queueing network model of the Leitner system for reviewing flashcards, along with a heuristic approximation that admits a tractable optimization problem for review scheduling. Finally, we empirically evaluate our queueing model through a Mechanical Turk experiment, verifying a key qualitative prediction of our model: the existence of a sharp phase transition in learning outcomes upon increasing the rate of new item introductions.
